The Wolf's Cookbook

Food By Geeks, For Geeks

According to Wikipedia, Dirty Rice is exta traditional Louisiana Creole dish made from white rice which gets a "dirty" color from being cooked with small pieces of pork, beef or chicken, green bell pepper, celery, and onion, and spiced with cayenne and black pepper. While that does cover the base form of the recipe, it can grow from that base to something with more complex flavors or custom mixes of spices, as this recipe should demonstrate.

Ingredients

  • Meats
    • 1 pound Ground Beef
      • To control the amount of grease in the dish, use 70/30 lean or better
  • Vegetables
    • 1 medium Red Bell Pepper
      • Somewhere between chopped and diced is fine
    • 1 medium Green Bell Pepper
      • Somewhere between chopped and diced is fine
    • 1 medium Yellow Onion Pepper
      • Somewhere between chopped and diced is fine
    • 1 stalk Celery
      • De-vein the celery for best effect
    • 3 cloves Garlic (minced)
    •  Chives
      • Optional ingredient, amount will vary according to cooks preference
  • Herbs and Spices
    • 1 tsp Salt
      • Separate into two one-half teaspoon measures - it is possible that not all the salt will be needed
    • 1 tsp Chili Powder
      • Your choice here of what to use
      • 'Chili Piquin Molido' from the Mexican Foods store near my home made this dish too spicy to really enjoy
    • 1 tsp Oregano
      • I recommend using ground Oregano rather than crushed here
    • ½ tsp Sage
      • You can use crushed, ground or fresh.
      • If using fresh sage, you may need to use less to not overpower the dish.
    • ½ tsp Ground Black Pepper
    • ¾ tsp Thyme
      • See notes on Sage
    • ¼ tsp Cayenne Pepper
      • If you are sensitive to spicy dishes, you can safely omit this
      • Replacing this with Chipotle Pepper might work, but isn't in line with the origins of the recipe
    • ¼ tsp Ground White Pepper
    • ¼ tsp Paprika
    • ¼ tsp Onion Powder
    • 2 Bay Leaves
  • Grains
    • 1 cup White Rice
      • A long-grain variety is preferred, but any variety of white rice can be used
  • liquids
    • 2 cups Beef Stock
      • You can use Chicken or Vegetable stock instead
    • 2 tsp Worcestershire Sauce
    •  Water
      • Amount will vary from none to several cups. This is needed to balance the amount of liquid needed for the rice to properly cook with the stock used.

Instructions

  1. Brown meat
  2. Add red bell pepper, onion, celery and half the salt. Cook while stirring frequently until veggies start to soften.
  3. Add rice, garlic, chives and dry seasonings - continue to stir until rice begins to toast.
  4. Add seasonings, worcestershire sauce, stock, water and bay leaves. Bring to a boil then turn down the heat and simmer until the rice is cooked. (use as much or as little of the remaining teaspoon of salt as needed to customize to taste)
  5. Remove Bay Leaves and let stand, covered, for five to ten minutes to settle before serving
